feed.title: SAP Community - SAP Cloud Application Programming Model
feed.subtitle: SAP Cloud Application Programming Model Q&A in SAP Community

entry.title: Use Microsoft Entra Id to Secure CAP Fiori Application
entry.content:
I have an HTML5 application developed using SAP Fiori and CAP for Node.js. An XSUAA instance was created for security, and the application uses the Build Work Zone Managed App Router.

I want users to be able to browse the app even if they don’t have a BTP account. However, if they are part of our Microsoft tenant, they should be able to access and use the site.

I’m not sure how to achieve this. Any suggestions or resources would be highly appreciated. Thanks.

entry.title: @cap-js/mcp-server - Practical guide to get value on day on
entry.content:
Give your coding assistant instant, project‑aware knowledge of your CAP model and docs. With @cap-js/mcp-server, the assistant can look up entities, services, fields, and HTTP endpoints from your compiled CDS model and cross‑check official CAP docs, so it proposes the right code and changes in your editor.

Here's where I found this and would like to share with community - https://github.com/cap-js/mcp-server

  • Package: @cap-js/mcp-server
  • Command: cds-mcp
  • Tools: search_model (compiled CDS/CSN), search_docs (local CAP docs embeddings)
  • Works with MCP‑capable assistants in VS Code and other IDEs (e.g., Cline, Copilot Agent Mode, opencode)

Here’s the short version - just follow these 3 step

  1. Configure your IDE agent to start the server via npx:
{
  "mcpServers": {
    "cds-mcp": {
      "command": "npx",
      "args": ["-y", "@cap-js/mcp-server"],
      "env": {}
    }
  }
}
  1. Add these rules to AGENTS.md so the assistant always uses the server correctly:
- You MUST search for CDS definitions, like entities, fields and services (which include HTTP endpoints) with cds-mcp, only if it fails you MAY read *.cds files in the project.
- You MUST search for CAP docs with cds-mcp EVERY TIME you create, modify CDS models or when using APIs or the `cds` CLI from CAP. Do NOT propose, suggest or make any changes without first checking it.
  1. Optional CLI smoke test:
npm i -g @cap-js/mcp-server
cds-mcp search_model . Books entity
cds-mcp search_docs "how to add columns to a select statement in CAP Node.js" 1

Why you’ll love it

  • Stop guessing: Fuzzy‑search your compiled model for entities, services, elements, annotations, and endpoints.
  • Fewer mistakes: Suggestions are grounded in your actual model and verified against official CAP docs.
  • All local: Fast and private, perfect for day‑to‑day development.

IDE setup

VS Code - Cline extension

Settings example:

{
  "mcpServers": {
    "cds-mcp": {
      "command": "npx",
      "args": ["-y", "@cap-js/mcp-server"],
      "env": {}
    }
  }
}

VS Code - GitHub Copilot Agent Mode (global mcp.json)

{
  "servers": {
    "cds-mcp": {
      "command": "npx",
      "args": ["-y", "@cap-js/mcp-server"],
      "env": {},
      "type": "stdio"
    },
    "inputs": []
  }
}

opencode

{
  "mcp": {
    "cds-mcp": {
      "type": "local",
      "command": ["npx", "-y", "@cap-js/mcp-server"],
      "enabled": true
    }
  }
}

Tip: Keep the server name “cds-mcp” in both your config and prompts so your assistant reliably calls it.

How to use it in your editor

Think “discover first, then change.” Ask your assistant to:

  • Discover model and endpoints

    • “Use cds‑mcp search_model to list all services and their HTTP endpoints. Then list entities with primary keys.”

  • Write a correct SELECT with expand

    • “Call cds‑mcp search_model for Books and its associations. Then, after checking CAP Node.js SELECT expand syntax via cds‑mcp search_docs, propose a handler that returns Books.title, Books.stock and expands auther.name.”

  • Generate precise OData URLs

    • “Find the service and endpoint for Books via search_model, then give me an OData V4 URL with $select=title,stock and $expand=author($select=name) plus a curl example.”

  • Safely change CDS/annotations

    • “Show docs for @Common.Label using cds‑mcp search_docs. Using search_model for Books, propose a minimal diff adding labels for title and stock. Include file paths.”

  • Plan a refactor

    • “We’re renaming Author to Writer. With cds‑mcp search_model, list affected entities, associations, services, and endpoints; propose a step‑by‑step PR plan.”

  • Implement an action/handler

    • “Find docs on defining and implementing a custom action in Node.js via cds‑mcp search_docs. Then sketch a minimal handler in srv/<service>.js with imports and input validation.”

Best practice: Ask the assistant to paste the search_model and search_docs results that justify any change.

CLI usage (optional but handy)

Install globally to test from your terminal:

npm i -g @cap-js/mcp-server
  • Search your compiled model:
cds-mcp search_model . Books entity
  • Search CAP documentation:
cds-mcp search_docs "how to add columns to a select statement in CAP Node.js" 1

Once the CLI works, your IDE agent can invoke the same tools automatically.

What the tools return

  • search_model

    • Names and kinds (entity, service, etc.)
    • Elements and annotations
    • File locations
    • HTTP endpoints where services are exposed

  • search_docs

    • The most relevant CAP documentation snippets for your query, based on local embeddings

Use both together: discover exact names/paths with search_model, confirm syntax and best practices with search_docs, then apply small, reviewable changes.

Tips for getting the most value

  • Start every task with search_model to avoid typos and stale assumptions.
  • Require docs‑backed edits: have the assistant run search_docs before proposing code.
  • Keep edits atomic: one focused change at a time, with file paths and minimal diffs.
  • Monorepo? Tell the assistant the CAP project folder to search.

Support and contribution

  • Issues and feature requests: https://github.com/cap-js/mcp-server/issues
  • Security policy: https://github.com/cap-js/mcp-server/security/policy
  • Code of Conduct: https://github.com/cap-js/.github/blob/main/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md
  • License and REUSE info: see LICENSE and https://api.reuse.software/info/github.com/cap-js/mcp-server

Now action - 

  • Add the MCP config, paste the two rules into AGENTS.md, and ask your assistant:
    “Discover all entities, keys, and endpoints with cds‑mcp search_model, verify the Node.js SELECT docs with cds‑mcp search_docs, then propose a minimal handler change for Books.”

    SAP Business Technology Platform  SAP Business AI SAP Cloud Application Programming Model

entry.title: What is the best development pattern or architecture to follow in SAP CAP Node.js projects
entry.content:
I’m working on a growing SAP CAP (Cloud Application Programming Model) project using Node.js, and the team wants to adopt a consistent development pattern or architecture to keep the codebase clean, maintainable, and scalable.

I’m familiar with general backend principles like SOLID, but I’m not sure how well they apply in CAP, since a lot of the database interaction is handled through CDS services, entities, and the framework’s built-in handlers.

So my question is:

What is the recommended architectural pattern for CAP Node.js development?
Should we try to follow something like SOLID, or are there CAP-specific or Node-oriented patterns that work better?

I’d appreciate guidance or examples on patterns such as:

  • Service / Handler separation
  • Domain-Driven Design (DDD)
  • Clean Architecture
  • Repository or Data Mapper patterns (and whether they make sense in CAP, since CDS services already abstract the DB)
  • Modularization strategies for large CAP projects
  • Any best practices from real CAP projects in production

If you have suggestions, examples, or official recommendations from SAP, that would be extremely helpful.

entry.title: Oauth2TechnicalUserPropagation in javascript
entry.content:
Hello everyone, I wanted to know what kind of configuration is needed to make an HTTP call with http/axios from SAP BTP CAP in NodeJS/javascript to an on-Premise system? I've tried with the Cloud SDK, but it does not support the Oauth2TechnicalUserPropagation  in the destination for HTTP calls (executeHttpRequest fails because of this).

I've tried making an axios call with the "SAP-Connectivity-Technical-Authentication" header, with proxy credentials that I can get from the destination, but that does not seem to work. So I wanted to know what was the full configuration needed to make a call with this setup to On-Premise system.

entry.title: CAP Deployment Stuck on "deploy-to-postgresql" – GCP Subaccount (Frankfurt)
entry.content:
Hello CAP developers,

Since yesterday, I’ve been unable to deploy a CAP application using PostgreSQL on SAP BTP. The deployment hangs at this step:

Executing task "deploy-to-postgresql" on application "name-of-app"

(Attached screenshot)

After this, the database doesn’t seem to work, and all CAP service calls fail.

Environment details:

  • Deployment method: cf deploy
  • Node.js: 20.19.3
  • npm: 11.4.1
  • CAP dependencies:
    "@cap-js-community/odata-v2-adapter": "^1.15.7",
"@cap-js/postgres": "^2.1.0",
"@sap-cloud-sdk/connectivity": "^4.0.2",
"@sap-cloud-sdk/http-client": "^4.0.2",
"@sap/cds": "^9.5.1",
"@sap/eslint-plugin-cds": "^3.1.2",
"dayjs": "^1.11.13"
  • Dev dependencies:
    "@cap-js/cds-types": "^0.15.0",
"@cap-js/sqlite": "^2.0.1",
"@sap/cds-dk": "^9.5.0"
  • PostgreSQL setup: via SAP BTP
  • Subaccount provider: GCP (Google Cloud)
  • Region: Europe (Frankfurt)
  • Recent changes: None
  • Logs: No errors shown
  • Service bindings: PostgreSQL service instance is correctly bound to the app

entry.title: Connect to Onprem LDAP Destination from CAP (Nodejs) App running in K8s cluster???
entry.content:
Hi All,

We have a requirement where we have to display users when a Cost Center value is entered.

We are looking to use LDAP protocol to fetch user details and have a working setup locally via ldap client

We have Kubernetes setup where we deploy our applications. We are looking for documentation/ gudance on how to connect to this on prem destination with SAP BTP connectivity service.

We use Transparent proxy, connectivity proxy intalled in the cluster and Destination and Connectivity services, cloud connector from BTP.

Though there is SAP help documentation, we dont have much clarity on how this can be done in CAP.

Looking forward for suggestions/support if someone has already implemented it.

We also interested in knowing if Default SAP IDP provides API's using which we can fetch the user data.

Thanks in Advance.

entry.title: I want to develop a Fiori app using capm service
entry.content: I have a service created using CAP (Cloud Application Programming Model), and I want to develop a Fiori application that can be deployed on a public URL, accessible to anyone. I need to know which approach I should follow: using a Page Map (Fiori Elements) or creating a Custom Page Fiori app.

entry.title: How to properly configure SAP CAP MCP Server so Codex can detect it?
entry.content:
I'm trying to configure Codex to detect and use the SAP CAP MCP Server, but Codex keeps saying that no MCP server is running, even though I can start it manually and see it listening on a port.

Here is what I tried so far:

mcp.json

{
"servers": {
"cds-mcp": {
"command": "npx",
"args": ["-y", "@cap-js/mcp-server"],
"env": {},
"type": "stdio"
}
},
"inputs": []
}

 

The SAP CAP MCP server appears to run correctly (screenshot attached), but Codex still reports:

config.toml (Codex)

[tools.mcp-server-cap]
type = "mcp"
command = "cds-mcp"
args = ["--port", "4005"]

 

Question

Has anyone managed to configure Codex with the CAP MCP server?
Is there something obvious I'm missing. Perhaps related to TCP vs STDIO mode or how Codex expects MCP servers to be declared?

Any help or working example would be greatly appreciated.

entry.title: CAP Multitenancy: Connectivity Service returns 401 invalid_client despite correct provisioning setup
entry.content:
I’m working on a CAP multitenant app in Cloud Foundry and I keep getting a 401 error when trying to use the Connectivity service, even though I’ve added it as a dependency both in my mta.yaml and in the provisioning dependencies handler. 
What makes this confusing is: I can successfully read subscriber destinations, but Connectivity fails even though it is also bound.

In my app:

  • Connectivity is listed as a dependency in mta.yaml
  • I return both the destination and connectivity xsappname in the dependencies handler
  • The xsappname values look correct in my environment variables
  • I’ve redeployed and double-checked the service bindings

But I still get this error:

Error: Could not fetch client credentials token for service of type connectivity: HTTP response ... was 401: {"error":"invalid_client","error_description":"Bad credentials"}

Main package versions:
@SAP-cloud-sdk/connectivity: ^4.2.0
@SAP-cloud-sdk/http-client: ^4.2.0
@SAP/cds: ^9.5.2
@SAP/cds-mtxs: ^3.5.1
@SAP/xssec: ^4

I have already reviewed the following SAP Community post and the related blog comments, but unfortunately the suggested approach did not resolve the issue in my case:

https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-q-a/cap-multitenancy-connectivity/qaq-p/12493182

Has anyone else run into this? Is there something I might be missing?
Any tips would be really appreciated!

Thanks!

entry.title: Cross Container Access Issue : object_owner and application user
entry.content:
Hi Experts, 

   I am working on cross container access , there are two types of roles that we define with Producer Project , one for the object_owner Role# and one for the application_user Role. We have attribute called privileges_with_grant_options, as per my knowledge , this attribute states what kind of privileges can be offered by a object_owner to application_user . 

In my project I have mentioned "SELECT" in my privileges_with_grant_options for Role# and I have mentioned "SELECT" , "INSERT" under privileges for Role.

Object Owner Role 

{
    "role":{
        "name":"EXTERNAL_ACESS_READ_G#",
        "object_privileges": [
            {
                "name":"PRODUCERNAMESPACE_PRODUCT",
                "type": "TABLE",
              
                "privileges_with_grant_option":["SELECT"] 
            }
        ]
    }
}

 Application User role 

{
    "role":{
        "name":"EXTERNAL_ACESS_READ",
        "object_privileges": [
            {
                "name":"PRODUCERNAMESPACE_PRODUCT",
                "type": "TABLE",
                "privileges": [
                    "SELECT","INSERT"
                ]
        
            }
        ]
    }
}

As per my understanding , this it should throw an error when I execute cds deploy --to hana it should throw error , stating INSERT cant be granted as there is no INSERT in  privileges_with_grant_option. Adding further Iam able to post it from Consumer app  Iam able to Post . What is the difference object_owner(schema_owner) and application_user.

Git Hub Repositories

https://github.com/Subramaniyam507/CrossHDIContainerProducer

https://github.com/Subramaniyam507/CrossHdiContainerConsumer 

Please help me with my query.

Thank you

entry.title: CAP - Hide/Show standard Create/Edit Buttons based on Roles
entry.content:
I have an list report / object page app where only one role has access to the Create/Edit/Delete buttons, other roles have read-only access. Authorisations have been defined in my annotations, however the Create/Edit/Delete buttons still show up in the app UI (pressing on them gives a Forbidden error).

annotate MyService.MyEntity with @(restrict: [
    {
        grant: 'READ',
        to   : ['LimitedRole']
    },
]);

Instead I would prefer to hide/disable those buttons for users with the read only roles. I tried following the example mentioned in the documentation here: https://cap.cloud.sap/docs/advanced/fiori#use-roles-to-toggle-visibility-of-ui-elements

However, I've found some options work and some do not. In terms of disabling buttons, I found that only the DeleteRestrictions has any effect:

annotate MyService.MyEntity with @(Capabilities: {
    // Disable Standard Buttons for non-admin roles (only works for Delete, no effect for Create and Edit)
    InsertRestrictions: {Insertable: {$edmJson: {$Path: '/MyService.EntityContainer/Configuration/isAdmin'}}},
    UpdateRestrictions: {Updatable: {$edmJson: {$Path: '/MyService.EntityContainer/Configuration/isAdmin'}}},
    DeleteRestrictions: {Deletable: {$edmJson: {$Path: '/MyService.EntityContainer/Configuration/isAdmin'}}},
});

In terms of hiding the standard buttons, this is a bit better as it works for both Edit and Delete, however it also does not effect the Create button.

annotate MyService.MyEntity with @(Capabilities: {
    // Hide Standard Buttons for non-admin roles (only works for Edit and Delete, no effect for Create)
    UI.CreateHidden: {$edmJson: {$Not: {$Path: '/CatalogService.EntityContainer/Configuration/isAdmin'}}},
    UI.UpdateHidden: {$edmJson: {$Not: {$Path: '/CatalogService.EntityContainer/Configuration/isAdmin'}}},
    UI.DeleteHidden: {$edmJson: {$Not: {$Path: '/CatalogService.EntityContainer/Configuration/isAdmin'}}},
});

 The strange thing to me is that since it works for Edit and Delete it shows that the path is correct and the isAdmin logic is also working correctly (console.log in the service handler also confirms this). If I hardcode UI.CreateHidden to true or 

InsertRestrictions:{Insertable to false, then both have the desired effect that I'm after.
 
So to me I've confirmed that the properties are correct for what I want to achieve (by hardcoding to true/false and testing), and the dynamic logic is correct in that is works partially for Edit and Delete. However, both annotations for the Create button only seem to work with a hardcoded true or false. Is there something else I'm missing?

entry.title: Issue with subscribing CAP Multitenant application from tenant subaccount
entry.content:
Hi Community,

I followed the CAP Multitenancy documentation and developed a multitenant application using the Bookshop example.

I am able to successfully deploy the application in the provider subaccount. However, when I try to subscribe to the application from a new (tenant) subaccount, the subscription fails.

Could you please guide me if I am missing any prerequisites or configuration steps required on either the provider or tenant subaccount side?

Any pointers or checklist for multitenant subscription readiness would be really helpful.

Thanks in advance for your support.


test(Subscriber subaccount) : 

 

 


trail(Provider) subaccount :

entry.title: Relationship on HANA Cloud Max Connections and CAP DB Connection Pools
entry.content:
Hello,
When two HDI containers that reference the same HANA Cloud instance are used by applications A and B respectively,
if the sum of the DB connections configured in applications A and B exceeds the maximum number of connections internally configured in HANA Cloud (which, as I understand, is SAP-managed and cannot be changed arbitrarily by customers),
could connection timeouts occur?

I expect that this could happen, but I would appreciate hearing others’ opinions, experiences, and any advice on possible solutions.

P.S. Tried Productivity tools as well as Cloud application approach.

entry.title: store credentials for destination in MTA file
entry.content:
Hello Experts

I am using the Destination service in SAP BTP, and the destination is consumed by an SAP CAP application (Node.js).

Currently, the destination is defined in mta.yaml, and for an on-premise system (via Cloud Connector) it requires BasicAuthentication.

I want to avoid hardcoding credentials (user/password) in mta.yaml.

What is the recommended and secure way to manage credentials for destinations used by CAP applications?

Any guidance or best practices for production scenarios would be appreciated.

- name: <name>-destination
  type: org.cloudfoundry.managed-service
  requires:
    - name: srv-api
  parameters:
    service: destination
    service-plan: lite
    config:
      HTML5Runtime_enabled: true
      init_data:
        instance:
          destinations:
            - Name: <name>-srv
              URL: ~{srv-api/srv-url}
              Authentication: NoAuthentication
              Type: HTTP
              ProxyType: Internet
              HTML5.ForwardAuthToken: true
              HTML5.DynamicDestination: true
              HTML5.Timeout: 600000

            - Name: ui5
              Authentication: NoAuthentication
              ProxyType: Internet
              Type: HTTP
              URL: https://ui5.sap.com

            - Name: S4_TECH
              URL: http://<ON_PREMISE_HOST>:<PORT>
              Type: HTTP
              ProxyType: OnPremise
              Authentication: BasicAuthentication
              User: "<TECH_USER>"
              Password: "<REDACTED>"
              sap-client: "<CLIENT>"
              CloudConnectorLocationId: "<LOCATION_ID>"
              Description: "Technical destination for nightly sync"
          existing_destinations_policy: update

entry.title: AMS instance-based (row-level) filtering not applied in CAP using dynamic user attributes
entry.content:
Issue: AMS instance-based filtering not working as expected in CAP
We are using AMS to implement row-level (instance-based) filtering in a CAP service. Below is a minimal reproducible example.

Schema
 
SCHEMA {
Supplier: String,
$user: {
supplierid: String
}
}
 
AMS Policy

POLICY ZSP_POLICY_MANAGER { GRANT read ON FPOReview WHERE Supplier = $user.supplierid; }

Service & Entity

service FPOService @(path: '/fpo-service')
{ entity FPOReview as projection on my.FPOReview { Supplier, * };
annotate FPOReview with @AMS.attributes: { Supplier: (Supplier) };
}
 
User Token (excerpt)
 
{ "supplierid": "17008974" }

Observed Behavior
When the user is assigned to policy ZSP_POLICY_MANAGER in IAS, the service returns all rows, instead of filtering records where Supplier = 17008974.
When we add @requires: ['ZSP_POLICY_MANAGER'] on the service or entity, the request starts failing with 403 Forbidden.

Questions
1. Is AMS expected to automatically apply row-level filtering based on @AMS.attributes and the policy condition (Supplier = $user.supplierid)?

2. Should assigning the policy alone be sufficient to filter records, or is @requires mandatory—and if so, why does it result in 403 Forbidden

Our requirement is to restrict data so that users only see records for suppliers assigned to them. While we can implement this manually in JavaScript handlers, we want to understand how AMS can be utilised for this use case, especially around dynamic attributes.

We are using a custom schema defined in IAS to obtain the supplier ID list. To simplify the initial testing and verify that dynamic attributes are working correctly, we have temporarily added a simple string attribute supplierid to the custom schema. We are able to successfully retrieve this value in our CAP application, but policies are not working.
